channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Georgia Businesses Begin to Reopen; Trump to Sign Aid Deal
item.description: The $484 billion relief package aims to prop up small businesses but has no money for state governments. The maker of Lysol and other disinfectants issued a warning against improper use of its products after President Trump touted their power to kill the virus.

item.title: How New Mexico, One of the Poorest States, Averted a Steep Death Toll
item.description: New Mexico showed how a state can fight the coronavirus with aggressive social distancing, free testing and scientific expertise. But contagion threats are building.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Eddie Moore/The Albuquerque Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Mexico’s governor, Michelle Lujan Grisham, moved quickly to guarantee free coronavirus testing for people in the state, including those not showing symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus Freed a Man Accused of Fleeing the Scene of a Fatal Accident
item.description: As outbreaks spread behind bars, more people are being released. But there is a growing conflict over who should be let out.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jails are setting free thousands of inmates to slow the coronavirus’s spread behind bars. Anthony Cromwell Jr. was released from Medium Security Institution in St. Louis, Mo.

item.title: ICE Detention Centers Approved in California Farm Town
item.description: Two privately run state prisons in the town of McFarland, many of whose residents are undocumented field workers, will be converted to hold immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the two privately run state prisons in McFarland, Calif., that will become federal immigration detention centers.

item.title: Preppers Are Quite Prepared to Enjoy Some Vindication
item.description: In Silicon Valley, gearing up for the apocalypse was a cliché. Now it’s a credential.
item.dc:creator: Nellie Bowles
item.media:credit: Bobby Doherty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Why is disaster prep so appealing to techies? Perhaps there is something about getting everything you have overnight that predisposes you to imagine losing it just as quickly.

item.title: Coronavirus, Congress, N.F.L. Draft: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: When Life Felt Normal: Your Pre-Pandemic Moments
item.description: Readers share memories, images and videos from before the coronavirus became a pandemic, and reflect on what they mean now.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Wise

item.title: Black Leaders Want a Black Woman as Biden’s Running Mate. But Who?
item.description: Among black leaders close to Joe Biden, a commitment to selecting a woman is not enough. They have publicly and privately pushed him to select a black woman to fuel black voter enthusiasm.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Curtis Compton/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Stacey Abrams and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. appeared at a church service in Selma, Ala., last month. She has been repeatedly mentioned as a potential running mate for Mr. Biden.

item.title: Canceled Spelling Bee? Not if These Siblings Can Help It
item.description: Shobha and Shourav Dasari have organized a national spelling bee after the Scripps tournament was canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic. It will take place online.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: Beeline: What Spelling Bees Reveal About Generation Z's New Path to Success (Book)
item.media:description: Shourav Dasari at age 13, during the finals of the 2016 National Spelling Bee, in National Harbor, Md.

item.title: Guerrilla Golfers Sneak Onto Greens Closed by Pandemic
item.description: Half of all golf courses are shut down. But across America — and especially in Florida — renegades are still getting their fix.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scott Eckert, a golfer in Boca Raton, drafted an online petition to reopen Palm Beach County’s courses. “There is a Bill of Rights,” he said, “and our civil liberties have been trashed.”

item.title: China's Elite Donate Coronavirus Gear to the U.S.
item.description: People and companies with vested interest in sustaining the U.S.-China relationship are stepping in as ties fray between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Nicholas Kulish and David Gelles
item.media:description: A plane carrying medical personal protective equipment from China being unloaded in Los Angeles.

item.title: Smithfield Meat Plant Conditions Assailed as Public Nuisance
item.description: A lawsuit filed against a Smithfield Foods plant claims it has created a public nuisance by failing to protect workers from coronavirus infection.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber and Michael Corkery
item.category: United Food and Commercial Workers Union
item.media:description: A Smithfield Foods pork plant in Milan, Mo., is at the center of a legal complaint about working conditions.

item.title: Trump Is Harsh on Immigration. That Doesn’t Mean Biden Has the Latino Vote.
item.description: Some Democrats worry that their party is taking a crucial bloc for granted in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers reciting the Pledge of Allegiance at the start of a Latinos for Trump meeting in Fairfax, Va., in November.

item.title: Trump Asks if Sunlight Can Kill Viruses. ‘Not as a Treatment,’ Birx Says.
item.description: At a briefing, the president promoted unproven treatments and asked Dr. Deborah Birx if she had heard of the success of sunlight as a tool against viruses.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad and Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a coronavirus briefing on Thursday. “Supposing we hit the body with a tremendous — whether it’s ultraviolet or just very powerful light,” he said.

item.title: Amazon Loses French Appeal to Sell Nonessential Items: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: An Amazon logistics center in Lauwin-Planque, in northern France. Amazon closed its six mammoth warehouses in France after a court order to stop selling nonessential items.

item.title: World Coronavirus News: Live Coverage
item.description: China reported no new coronavirus deaths for at least the seventh straight day. Pakistani doctors warn that the country is loosening its lockdown too soon.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: People line up to enter the Wazir Akbar Khan mosque for Friday Prayer in Kabul, Afghanistan, on the first day of Ramadan.

item.title: Bodies of 2 Transgender Women Found in Badly Burned Car in Puerto Rico
item.description: Activists said that the women, who were from New York City, were the third and fourth transgender people to be killed in Puerto Rico in the last two months.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: The Facebook profile photo of Serena Angelique Velázquez, one of two transgender women killed this week in Puerto Rico.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: With evidence mounting that the coronavirus was circulating undetected for weeks, Americans are wondering whether they may already have had Covid-19 and not known it.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: House to Examine Ouster of Health Official Who Doubted Drugs Trump Pushed
item.description: The chairwoman of the Energy and Commerce health subcommittee said she planned to hold hearings on Rick Bright’s dismissal as the head of an agency helping to develop a coronavirus vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.category: House Committee on Energy and Commerce
Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: “I think the American people deserve to know what happened here,” said Representative Anna G. Eshoo, the chairwoman of the House Energy and Commerce health subcommittee.

item.title: ‘I Wasn’t Happy With Brian Kemp,’ Trump Says
item.description: The president’s criticism of Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia, a Republican reopening the state amid a viral pandemic, sent a confusing message to governors considering similar moves.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
item.media:description: Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia, a Republican, has had his decision-making questioned by President Trump in White House briefings this week.

item.title: Don Campbell, Hip-Hop Dance Innovator, Is Dead at 69
item.description: He invented the Campbellock, better known as locking, an idiosyncratic style that became one of the first street dances to gain widespread attention.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

item.title: Trump and the Coronavirus: A Sour President, Home Alone at the White House
item.description: As his administration grapples with reopening the economy and responding to the coronavirus crisis, President Trump worries about his re-election and how the news media is portraying him.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Annie Karni
item.media:description: President Trump’s internal polling has shown his approval rating sliding in some swing states.

item.title: Was It Covid? Americans Ask Amid Signs the Coronavirus Came Earlier
item.description: New revelations have left people wondering about ailments early this year. Doctors are thinking back to unexplained cases. Medical examiners are looking for possible misdiagnosed deaths.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Amy Harmon and Thomas Fuller
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Malika Abdulkhsanova explained how to test for the virus at a site in Brooklyn, N.Y., last week.

item.title: Treasury Clarifies Small-Business Loans as Fed Vows Transparency
item.description: The two institutions, actively deploying hundreds of billions of dollars in taxpayer funding, moved to assuage concerns about where the money is going.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Shake Shack, with 189 outlets and nearly 8,000 employees in the United States, said it would return the $10 million small business emergency loan it had received.

item.title: Your View of Staying Home
item.description: We heard thoughts from readers across the country about efforts to reopen states that are currently social distancing to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: House Passes Relief for Small Businesses and Aid for Hospitals and Testing
item.description: The chamber also established a special committee to investigate the Trump administration’s response to the coronavirus pandemic and the multitrillion-dollar government rescue effort enacted to address it.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday at the Capitol. “We have our differences, but we are coming together on this particular bill,” she said.

item.title: Financial Aid to Struggling States Is Next Big Congressional Battle
item.description: Mitch McConnell said states should file for bankruptcy, but there is broad agreement that Washington will have to bail out local governments suffering economic pain from the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: A food distribution center in New York. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said federal funding was desperately needed to get the state back on its feet.

item.title: Movie Theaters, Urged to Open, Want to Delay Showtime
item.description: The major chains, with no new releases to show and a fear of being singled out as virus hot spots, are worried about coming back too early.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: “Hell no, we’re not opening on Monday,” the owner of the Plaza in Atlanta said.

item.title: C.D.C. Stresses Need for Coronavirus Testing at Homeless Shelters
item.description: A study of four cities suggested that those living in close quarters in shelters can spread the virus at high rates even when asymptomatic.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A temporary men’s shelter set up at the Exhibition Hall of the Seattle Center earlier this month.

item.title: Coronavirus Forces School Districts to Adapt
item.description: Schools thrust into turmoil by the coronavirus are slowly finding ways to cope.
item.dc:creator: Chris Berdik
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Beech Street School in Manchester, N.H., milk was loaded into school buses to deliver to students and their families on April 10.

item.title: Richard Sobol, Civil Rights Lawyer in the South, Dies at 82
item.description: Unlike other Northern lawyers who joined the struggle in the South, he stayed, and won a landmark case.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Richard Sobol during a civil rights protest march in Louisiana in August 1967. He took on civil rights cases often at great personal risk and under threat of violence.

item.title: Teachers of Special-Needs Students Struggle With Feelings of Helplessness
item.description: Remote learning has proved challenging for students who need intensive one-on-one guidance.
item.dc:creator: Alina Tugend
item.media:description: The dining room of Danielle Kovach of Succasunna, N.J., a teacher, has been turned into a one-room schoolhouse. While her sons, from left, Ryan, 12; Joseph, 15; and Michael, 19, were studying recently, she held an online grammar class with her students with special needs.

item.title: Marine Corps Bans Public Display of Confederate Flag
item.description: In a letter, Gen. David H. Berger, the Marine commandant, said the symbol had “the power to inflame division.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: In a letter posted Thursday, Gen. David Berger, the Marine commandant, emphasized the importance of building a team without divisions.

item.title: Performers and Artists Turn to Online Video in Pandemic
item.description: The pandemic has disrupted the creative lives of everyday Americans who used to spend untold hours together singing, dancing and making art, sometimes for money, always with love.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: Ray Spears, a street photographer based in New York, took this photo of skaters near his home in Harlem. He has mostly stayed indoors or close to home these days. “I am very scared, but also, I have time to think about what I’ve done and where I’ve come from, which is great for me.”

item.title: Class Is in Session Everywhere Now
item.description: Around the country, museums, libraries, zoos and even federal agencies are offering lessons, activities and fun for learners of all ages.
item.dc:creator: Ted Loos
item.category: Los Angeles County Museum of Art

item.title: Community College of Rhode Island Is Forced to Adapt
item.description: Well-run colleges are known for thoughtful planning and execution. The pandemic made the Community College of Rhode Island work in a new way, instantaneously.
item.dc:creator: Meghan Hughes
item.media:credit: Craig F. Walker/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the Rhode Island Army National Guard prepared to process patients a testing site at the Community College of Rhode Island’s Knight Campus in Warwick earlier this month.

item.title: Clean Water Act Covers Groundwater Discharges, Supreme Court Rules
item.description: In a 6-to-3 ruling, the court rejected arguments by a county in Hawaii and the Trump administration that only pollution discharged directly into navigable waters requires permits.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: Justice Stephen G. Breyer, center, writing for the majority in the 6-to-3 ruling, rejected both sides’ positions in the case as too extreme.

item.title: Nearly All Patients Hospitalized With Covid-19 Had Chronic Health Issues, Study Finds
item.description: Only 6 percent of patients at one New York area health system had no chronic conditions. Hypertension, obesity and diabetes were common.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: An intubated patient arriving at Lenox Hill Hospital Northwell Health in Manhattan earlier this month.

item.title: Most People Back Stay-at-Home Orders. Here’s Why Some Are Protesting Them.
item.description: A vocal minority is pressing for an end to restrictions despite the continued spread of the coronavirus. “Not everybody can put on their fashionable loungewear and get on Zoom,” a protester said.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Sabrina Tavernise and Mike Baker
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at the State Capitol in Olympia, Wash., on Sunday to challenge stay-at-home orders.

item.title: Donald Kennedy, Who Led Stanford in 1980s, Dies at 88
item.description: As president, he expanded the university and battled a government inquiry into its research expenses. He also headed the F.D.A. under President Carter.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: In Wisconsin, Virus Creates New Front in Long-Simmering Partisan Wars
item.description: Protests planned for Friday continue a decade-long partisan cleaving in the state and serve as a stand-in for the general election battle to come.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liberals were galvanized to protest at the Wisconsin state Capitol in 2011 by former Gov. Scott Walker’s move to end collective bargaining rights for the state’s public employees.

item.title: Donald Reed Herring, Brother of Elizabeth Warren, Dies From Coronavirus
item.description: Mr. Herring, 86, was “charming and funny, a natural leader,” Ms. Warren wrote.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Darren Durlach/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Elizabeth Warren with her three brothers in Oklahoma City in November 2011. Donald Reed Herring is center.

item.title: ‘Florida Is a Terrible State to Be an Unemployed Person’
item.description: Florida has emerged as one of the slowest states in the nation to process an avalanche of unemployment claims since the coronavirus hit.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ernst Virgile was able to get a claim lodged in Florida’s overwhelmed system in early April. But he has yet to see a penny of unemployment compensation.
